ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS

(New concessionary loan policies)

     1. Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman asked the Minister for National Development since the implementation of HDB's new concessionary loan policies in January 2003, (a) how many applicants have appealed for such concessionary loans because of their failure to secure such housing loans from commercial banks; (b) how many of these appeals have been successful; and (c) whether HDB will

Column: 139

review its policy further in light of the cases for concessionary loans.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, since 1st January 2003, HDB has ceased to provide market rate loans for certain categories of buyers.  These include permanent residents, private property owners and high-income earners.  In addition, those who have already enjoyed two concessionary loans and 2nd-timer households who have already enjoyed a concessionary loan and are buying a flat of the same or a smaller size are also ineligible. As HDB concessionary loans are subsidised by the Government, HDB has to ensure that they are given to those who need them most.

 

     So far, HDB has processed 401 appeals for concessionary loans of which 51 were approved.  The majority of the unsuccessful appeals were rejected because they could finance their flat purchases from the sales proceeds of their existing flats, or because they were not financially ready to buy a flat at that point in time usually because they did not have a steady income or their current income was insufficient to meet HDB's credit guidelines.  Of the remaining cases, many had alternative accommodation.  And there were also some existing lessees who had difficulty in servicing their mortgage instalments, whom HDB advised to remain in their existing flats and instead take up one of the various assistance schemes that the HDB has in place.

 

     HDB has no plans to change its current mortgage loan policy.  Nonetheless, it will continue to exercise flexibility and take into account the individual

Column: 140

circumstances of the buyers when they are considering requests for HDB concessionary loans.

     Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman (Sembawang):  Sir, with regard to those who choose to downgrade, one of the reasons is that they are not able to manage their current obligation.  Would the HDB consider this on grounds that they actually are not able to pay, that is why they want to downgrade?  But the restriction disallows them to do so.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  Mr Speaker, Sir, we are aware that some need to downgrade because of financial circumstances.  Our policy is to review each and every single case carefully.  And, in particular, if any person has problems because of retrenchment, a severe pay cut, business failure, prolonged illness or death of the sole breadwinner, these are the types of cases which we would certainly look at very sympathetically.  If any of the Members have residents in these circumstances, please support their appeals.

     Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang):  May I ask the Minister whether he knows of cases where residents are unable to get loans from commercial banks and as a result wanted to have an HDB loan, whether it is concessionary loan or not, and they would like HDB to assist.  Is there any policy regarding such cases?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I think we need to study those cases carefully.  Sometimes when a bank declines to issue a loan, it often indicates that perhaps it is not an opportune time for that person to purchase a flat of that size.  He or she might be overextending himself or herself and really we are not doing them a favour.  For cases like these, they often have to look either for alternatives or look for a smaller flat.  Very

Column: 141

often, the sales proceeds from the existing flat are sufficient for them to buy a smaller flat, although it may not be in a location or a size of their preference.  But like I said earlier, wherever possible, we will exercise maximum flexibility in applying this policy.

     Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman:  Sir, is it true that residents who would like to add a family member as a co-lessee, because they are not able to pay the current mortgage loan and their child perhaps may be able to help, such transaction is considered as a new transaction and therefore they would have to apply for a commercial bank loan and not be entitled to another HDB loan?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  Mr Speaker, Sir, we have assistance schemes.  One of them is to include more family members so that they can help to pay for the loan.  In those cases, we would certainly help them  maximally, in order for them not to have any disruption and not to have to move out of the flat that they are living in.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member):  Mr Speaker, Sir, can I clarify with the Minister?  Where a child's name is added to the list, the child is actually considered as a first-time purchaser and he would not actually qualify for concessionary loans in future if he is getting married and buying another property.  Am I correct to say that?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  If his name is added, it would be tagged as having enjoyed his first bite of the subsidy cherry.  If he subsequently purchases a flat, then we would have to review the case again and make sure that he has not inordinately consumed housing subsidies.  But like I said, I think the main point which I want to emphasise, and I want to repeat, is that although this policy is in place, the HDB is bending backwards to exercise flexibility to help

Column: 142

people who truly need help.

 

     But let us also be cognisant of the fact that some people who, at a certain point in time, should not over-extend themselves and should not be purchasing a flat that is beyond their means.  As long as we remember these two extremes and we help people in the most appropriate fashion, no Singaporeans would be deprived of housing; no Singaporeans would be turfed out unnecessarily.  The key point is to help people appropriately.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong:  Mr Speaker, Sir, if a family member is asked to lend his name to help the family in a crisis so that they can actually tide over the loan, how can that be considered as him taking a first bite of the cherry when he has not set up his family in the future?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  Mr Speaker, I do not want to get too involved in a technical discussion which I can take off-line.  There are many ways to help.  If a person is just helping by contributing money to pay for the loan, he is not tagged as an owner.  If he is not listed as an owner and is not using his CPF account, he is not tagged at all as having consumed his first bite of the subsidy cherry.  But I think these are cases where we have to look at individually.  And I would assure all Members that we will do our best to assist each and every family in the unlikely event that they run into problems.

IMPORT OF PORK FROM MALAYSIA

     2. Dr Teo Ho Pin asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether his Ministry has any plans to allow import of pork from Malaysia and (b) what are the measures in place to ensure that pork prices are competitive in Singapore.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Agri-Food and Veterinary

Column: 143

Authority (AVA) has to ensure that all food approved for import into Singapore from a very wide range of sources is safe to eat.  Pork can be imported from AVA-approved sources which meet Singapore's current food safety and animal health requirements.

 

     Import of pigs from Malaysia was stopped from March 1999 due to the outbreak of the Nipah disease which affected pigs and humans (farmers and abattoir workers) who are in contact with the infected animals.  In addition, Malaysia has also not been recognised by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) as foot-and-mouth disease free.   AVA is currently discussing with its Malaysian counterpart the requirements for the export of frozen pork to Singapore.  And we will have to ensure that the requirements will be in line with international standards and practices.

 

     Singapore has an open market.  There are 19 countries approved by AVA to export pork to Singapore.  AVA has a programme to increase the number of sources that Singapore can import pork from.  The availability of pork from multiple sources will help to ensure that pork prices in Singapore remain competitive.

     Dr Teo Ho Pin (Holland-Bukit Panjang):  Sir, may I just clarify with the Minister of State.  He said that Malaysia is not recognised by the World Organisation for Animal Health as foot-and-mouth disease free.  Does it mean that it is not safe to consume pork in Malaysia?  So, what is the advice to Singaporeans who travel to Malaysia?

 

     Secondly, the prices of lean pork actually have increased quite a lot since 1999.  It could be due to the demand of Singaporeans to consume lean pork.  By increasing the supply, the demand is more for

Column: 144

fresh pork, not frozen pork.  So maybe the Minister can clarify on that.

 

     The third point is that there is a difference between frozen pork and fresh pork.  I think we need to increase the sources of fresh pork, so that at least that will bring the prices down for fresh pork.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Member for the questions.   I will handle them in reverse order.

 

 

   Our current consumption of pork can be classified into three categories:  fresh, chilled and frozen.  Today, it is one-third each.  I appreciate the Member's preference, and many people's preference, for fresh pork.  Currently, we import about 1,000 pigs a day from the island of  Bulan.  These pigs are imported into Singapore and they are slaughtered in order to produce fresh pork.  The key thing which we have to remember when dealing with fresh pork - and you are importing live animals - is that there is a significant safety issue, not just for consumers but for everyone who is involved in the import, the slaughter and the preparation of that meat.  The AVA has repeatedly checked and audited the conditions in Bulan.  It is a quarantined island.  In that sense, we are very confident that it is safe to import those pigs and it does not pose a public health risk to Singapore.

 

     When we talk about importing live pigs from other sources, we have to be equally sure that those sources are safe and will not pose a threat either as a public health threat or an economic threat.  Nipah virus is an example of a public health threat.  The foot-and-mouth

Column: 145

disease in pigs is not the same as the human hand-foot-and-mouth disease.  Let me emphasise that you do not catch hand-foot-and-mouth disease from contact with pigs with foot-and-mouth disease.  Nevertheless, foot-and-mouth disease in pigs is an economic threat.  Because once a country is labelled as having been infected with foot-and-mouth disease, it affects its ability to import, export or to tranship meat products.  From that perspective, Singapore cannot afford to go on the red list of countries with foot-and-mouth disease. That is why our caution with importing any animal from another country which is labelled as having endemic foot-and-mouth disease. 

 

 

    Nevertheless, we are working with our Malaysian counterparts, in particular in the state of Johore.  I am confident that as they raise standards there and we work together, when the international organisation is prepared to certify Johore for a start, as foot-and-mouth disease free and we are confident that there is no public health risk of Nipah, then we can start importing from Johore.  I have personally met the representatives from Johore and I have told them that we will do this step by step.  Get international certification first, then we will move on as our first step to look into the possibility of importing frozen pork.  You will ask why frozen pork, why not chilled,


why not fresh pork.  The difference with frozen pork is that there is time for AVA to test the consignment to make sure it is safe.  With chilled pork, you cannot hold it and test and then release it to the markets.  And with fresh pork, you get all the other problems and potential complications that  I told you about.  So I want to assure Members of the House that we are actively looking to increase our source of pork.  But we will do it safely, we will do it step by step, and we will do it in collaboration with potential exporters.

 

     The Member's point about the price of pork is a valid one, and that is why AVA is actively sourcing for more and more sources of exports, ie, from people who can export pork to us.  The current major source of pork for Singapore is Australia and, as you know, the grain prices have

Column: 146

risen because of the drought.  The grain is needed to feed the pigs and also their exchange rate has increased compared to the Singapore dollar.  All these things have contributed to the increase in the pork price over the last few months.

 

     I want to also assure Members that we are also getting large amounts of pork from Brazil and China and, in fact, the extent of supply from China is increasing.  And as all these supplies come in, we hope eventually to stabilise and, hopefully, bring down the price of pork.  But this is a commodity which is internationally traded.  We cannot unilaterally force and artificially bring the price down. 

 

     On the Member's point about advising the travellers, I think all of us are travellers and all of us need to take our appropriate precautions and, ultimately, take our own risks.  The AVA, unfortunately, cannot and should not be in a position to certify the safety of all food all over the world.  That is the job which we cannot perform.  But in any country that you go to, be aware of what you are eating, what the regulatory system is and make your own informed choices. 

     Dr Teo Ho Pin:  Sir, just now, the Minister of State mentioned that the reason why we import frozen pork is that we need time to test the pork.  So how does AVA test the 1,000 pigs coming to Singapore every day?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  That is precisely the point.  When you are dealing with 1,000 live pigs, you cannot hold them all out and test every single one of them for every single step.  So the key point is you accredit the source, you accredit the transport system that brings them in, you accredit and check and audit the abattoir and then for those of you who have ever been to an abattoir, you will see our AVA officers at very odd times of the day, very early part of the

Column: 147

morning, actually checking the carcasses.  So there is, whether you realise it or not, a very stringent system of checks on our food supply, and this is something we should not take for granted.  If we were to alter it and lower our guard, we will do so at our own peril. 

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong:  Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister actually give us an estimated timeframe when the international accreditation from the Malaysian farms would be completed and when can we actually start importing the pigs from Malaysia?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  Mr Speaker, Sir, as this involves an international organisation and a foreign country, I am not in a position to make any commitment as to the timeframe.

DOLPHINS ACQUIRED BY UNDERWATER WORLD

(Investigations)

     3. Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Minister for National Development (a) if he will give an update on the investigations by the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) following a report claiming that the dolphins acquired by Underwater World were not born in captivity but were illegally traded after their capture in the wild; and (b) how does the AVA ensure that animals brought in or bought by local operators do not contravene the Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, to which Singapore is a signatory.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan (for the Minister for National Development):  Mr Speaker, Singapore is a signatory to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).  The CITES regulates the international

Column: 148

trade in endangered species to ensure that they are not threatened with extinction. The Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority is the CITES Management Authority in Singapore. Under Singapore's Endangered Species (Import and Export) Act, any import of species that is protected under CITES requires an import permit from AVA as well as an export permit from the exporting country.  AVA will only issue permits for imports that meet CITES' requirements. The consignment of CITES species will be inspected by AVA officers at the point of entry to ensure compliance with CITES and with AVA requirements before it is released to the importer.

 

    The acquisition of the six Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins, or pink dolphins, from Thailand by the Underwater World Singapore (UWS) did not contravene CITES' requirements.  CITES allows the import of both wild and captive bred pink dolphins for captive breeding and education purposes if it is approved by the exporting country and if there are sufficiently equipped facilities to house and to care for the animals in the importing country. Thailand, as a signatory to CITES, had approved the export of the dolphins to Singapore. The AVA had assessed that the Underwater World Singapore, as a zoological facility, had met all CITES' requirements and, hence, approved the application.

     Ms Braema Mathiaparanam:  Two supplementary questions,  Sir.  The Minister of State mentioned that, according to CITES, as long as it is wild or bred in captivity, it allows it to be imported.  I am a little bit lost here as to what is the definition of "wild" if it is an endangered species when you are going to bring it and keep it within a specific area.  How did that dolphin then come about to be?  Is it captured in the wild then?  Could I have some clarification on that?  According to the report in the newspaper, the Oasis Seaworld was founded in 1990.  The dolphins that came here, the average age,

Column: 149

according to the report, is about 26.

     Mr Speaker:  Ms Braema, no speeches.  Your question, please.

     Ms Braema Mathiaparanam:   They could not have been bred in captivity then.  So how were the records checked?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  Mr Speaker, Sir, the definition of "wild" means it is caught in the wild.  Definition of "captive bred" means it has been bred in a zoological facility.  Of the six dolphins, some, we believe, would have been caught, and some are captive bred.  The point is that it is a red herring - if you can pardon the pun - whether they are captive bred or wild.  Under Appendix 1 of CITES, as long as AVA is confident, that the Underwater World Singapore is able to take appropriate care of these dolphins, they are allowed to be imported, regardless of whether they are captive bred or wild. 

     Ms Braema Mathiaparanam:  Could I have the assurance from the Minister that in the way we have given the permit, we have not contravened the Convention then?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  Mr Speaker, Sir, absolutely.

LAW ON SEXUAL OFFENCES

(Review)

    

     4. Mr R Ravindran asked the Minister for Home Affairs in the light of the changed societal norms and values whether his Ministry will appoint a Committee to review the law on sexual offences in Singapore.

    

     5. Mr Chandra Mohan K Nair asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether section 377 (and perhaps section 377A) of the Penal Code (Chapter 224) will be reviewed with a view to amending, repealing or clarifying by way of

Column: 150

"Explanation", "Exception" or "Illustration".

     The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs):  Mr Speaker, Sir, may I take Question Nos. 4 and 5 together?

     Mr Speaker:  Yes, please do.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:  Thank you.  Sir, MHA is currently reviewing the Penal Code in consultation with the Ministry of Law and the Attorney-General's Chambers.  The aim of the review is to update the offences and penalties in the Penal Code to stay relevant in today's context.

 

     Sections 377 and 377A are being examined as part of this review.  Current societal norms will be taken into account in examining these sections.  For section 377, one option being considered is to decriminalise consensual oral sex between a male and female so long as it is done in private and both of them are above 16 years of age.  The fact is there has not been any prosecution for consensual oral sex in private between a male and female for many years, except in cases involving minors or those who are physically or mentally vulnerable.

 

     Sir, there are several other provisions in the Penal Code and other legislation, such as the Children and Young Persons Act and the Women's Charter, that cover different sexual offences. In line with Mr Ravindran's suggestion, we will study if there is a need to expand, clarify or dovetail the scope of some of these offences. The review committee will consult MHA's Government Parliamentary Committee of which Mr Ravindran is Deputy Chairman, as well as other relevant Ministries and agencies, as appropriate.  We expect to complete our review of sexual offences in two to three months' time.

 

Column: 151

    Mr Mohan asked if we would be amending, repealing or clarifying section 377 or section 377A by way of "explanation", "exception" or "illustration".  Sir, this is a technical matter, concerning drafting approach, which is for the legal draftsmen to consider once the policy considerations have been settled.  MHA will consult the Attorney-General's Chambers on the most appropriate approach to effect changes to the law.

DENGUE OUTBREAK IN BRADDELL HEIGHTS ESTATE

     6. Mr R Ravindran asked the Minister for the Environment (a) what are the causes of the dengue outbreak in Braddell Heights estate; (b) what measures have been taken by the Ministry to eradicate the dengue outbreak; and (c) whether these measures have been successful.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Swee Say):  Mr Speaker, Sir, on 16th September, the National Environment Agency (NEA) was notified by MOH of six dengue cases in Serangoon Avenues 2 and 3. NEA took immediate action to fog the area to get rid of adult Aedes mosquitoes.  Fogging was repeated for a few weeks.

 

 

    On the same day, NEA officers started door-to-door visits to distribute advisory letters and educational pamphlets on dengue prevention to the residents.  They also inspected households, construction sites and outdoor places to search and destroy breeding grounds.  In total, NEA found breedings in 63 households, a junior college, a construction site and on the roof covers of two water tanks at two HDB blocks.

 

     To increase public awareness and to step up public education, NEA contacted the grassroots organisations on

Column: 152

7th October.  More than 30 volunteers from the Residents' Committees (RC) joined in to help distribute the letters and pamphlets to the residents.  By 11th October, all households in Serangoon Avenues 2 and 3 and 1,600 households in the surrounding area, including Braddell Heights estate, were covered.  A roving exhibition was also held on weekends in the HDB void decks to inform residents about dengue and the preventive measures that they could take.  The RC volunteers also helped to put up posters in the lift lobbies of the HDB blocks to raise public awareness.

 

     Sir, with the strong support and active participation of the grassroots leaders and residents, the outbreak was brought under control by 12th October.

 

    Since then, another outbreak involving four cases occurred in Serangoon Avenue 2 on 19th December.  This time round, NEA immediately informed the CCC chairman on the same day and educational pamphlets were distributed again to the residents in the area with the help of RC volunteers. Fogging again was carried out and mosquito-breeding habitats that were found were destroyed.  There were far fewer breeding habitats as a result of the heightened awareness this time round.  No new cases have been reported in the current cluster. So with the early involvement of the community, the outbreak was more limited and came under control within a shorter time by 29th December, in other words, in 10 days.

 

     Sir, Singapore is located in a region where dengue virus and Aedes mosquitoes are prevalent.  From time to time, there would be localised outbreaks of dengue.  Community support and participation is vital in our efforts to reduce the incidents of dengue outbreaks. NEA will continue with public education.  At the same time, from now on, NEA will

Column: 153

also draw on greater community involvement much sooner.  It will notify the grassroots advisors, grassroots organisations and medical clinics in the affected areas much earlier than its past practice.  In this way, the community is alerted much earlier, and can respond more speedily too. Working together, we believe we can reduce the incidents of dengue outbreaks, and bring any outbreak under control as quickly as possible.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua: Mr Speaker, Sir, broadening the scope of the Human Organ Transplant Act is a right move, given that this would mean more people who are ill will be able to get a second chance to lead a normal life.  However, there are a few issues which should be addressed under the proposed amendment to the Act.

the doctor who sits on the Committee should not be connected to the hospital.  One would assume that the guiding principle of having this Committee is to have people who are independent-minded, making decisions to the best interest of the public.  Therefore, there should be a time limitation for the service with the hospital to avoid a situation where they become too familiar with the hospital.

Is there a guideline from the Ministry for hospitals to comply with?

 

Definition of death

 

    Since the scope of the Bill is broadened to include any cause of death and not due to any accident or otherwise, it is important that a new definition of when is a person considered to be dead be spelt out.  Currently, two senior medical practitioners who possess appropriate post-graduate medical qualifications can certify the death of a person.  This is provided: (i) they do not belong to the medical team that is involved in the organ removal; (ii) they are not involved in the care and treatment of the organ recipient; and (iii) their medical qualifications are recognised by the Ministry.

 

     As the Bill now stands, everything is left to the opinion of the two medical practitioners.  The families of the deceased would surely want to know, as a matter of fact, how is death determined.  In the US, the definition apparently varies between some states.  One definition is when a person experiences an irreversible cessation of spontaneous respiratory and circulatory functions.  Another definition says there is an absence of spontaneous respiratory and cardiac functions, and because of the disease or condition which causes directly or indirectly these functions to cease, or because of the passage of time since these functions have ceased, attempts at resuscitation are considered hopeless and, in this event, death would have occurred at the time these functions have ceased.

 

    We should make it clear in the Act so that there is no ambiguity in the determination of death.  The next-of-kin, as you will well imagine, will be under a lot of trauma and distress when such a decision is to be taken.  If the Act spells out the definition in a clear manner that a layman can understand, then the process will be less painful for the families of the

Column: 183

deceased persons.  And I agree with Mrs Lim Hwee Hua's comment that the concern here is not solely on principle nor legality, but the added dimension or sufficiency of safeguards.  And we have also been recently reminded of the accidents resulting in the training of commandos.  Additional external checks should be done on a periodic basis so that comprehensive safeguards on the process of the certification of death are constantly present.

     There are many people who do see the merits of organ donation as an act of saving lives.  However, they also believe that organ donation is an altruistic act and not to be carried out through an act of law.  In this view, some may choose to opt out and then opt in through MTERA, or some are already in MTERA for many years.  I would like to stay that way.  Can the Act recognise this spirit of altruistic act of organ donation and recognise the individual choice, since the end result is the same?

in the event of death.  This is an important information that should be carefully explained to the people and we should make sure that it is filtered down with the correct messages.  No one would want to see their loved ones lying in this condition with the thought at the back of their minds that the body they see is, in fact, devoid of the cornea, liver, heart and kidney, unless they strongly believe in the merits of the removal of the body organs to save lives.  Hospitals should provide sufficient qualified counsellors to handle this highly charged state of emotive condition of the family members, especially when the donors are young.  The Government should also muster the support of grassroots organisations, welfare bodies, religious bodies to help in this process.  Here is the process in which once a decision is taken, the outcome is irreversible.  The consequences can be very painful and traumatic as they haunt the conscience of the living for the rest of his or her life.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, I rise in support of the amendment Bill.  It is encouraging to note that many seriously ill people are saved each year through organ donations.  At the same time it is just as depressing to note that yet many more die each year, because there are simply not enough organs donated.

Legalising the sale of organs would also remove the incentive for illegal profiteering from the trade. Opponents, include Alistair Campbell, Professor of Medical Ethics at Bristol University, who argued "Our body is not a piece of property in the sense that our house is.  Also the consequence of a market in human organs is inevitably exploitative, as studies from countries like India have shown."  According to Campbell, "Far from improving the lot of the poor, it worsens their situation.  The notion of an 'ethical market' is a myth and it will only be the most needy who are ready to sell organs."

    In Singapore, the prescribed tests for brain death set out in our Interpretation Regulations in 1998 were lifted from our old Rule 3 of HOTA 1987.  Both were based on the brain function tests developed in the US, 20 years ago.  The pertinent question is: have there been no new advances, medical breakthroughs, or change in medical consensus since then?  I understand that Singapore doctors use EEG and other confirmatory tests to determine brain death.  I urge the Government to review the prescribed tests for brain death to keep pace with the medical practice in Singapore.

 

    Apart from the prescribed tests for brain death in Singapore, I also urge the Government to review the medical procedure in organ transplant from brain dead bodies.  Literature from the US, UK and Australia shows that brain dead bodies are maintained on life support systems up to, and perhaps throughout, the harvesting and organ transplant procedure.  This practice keeps their organs in optimum condition for transplants.  The brain dead body is not allowed to shut down its bodily functions naturally.  Hence, the "torso jerks" and "arms and legs flail about" as described by some doctors in the UK and Australia.

 

     I believe that many sections of the public will find this practice distasteful.  Even if a body is brain dead (and I mean cessation of all brain functions, as defined in our Interpretation Act), many sections of the public will still expect that the brain dead body be allowed to "shut down" its bodily functions, so to speak, before the harvesting begins.  We treat a motorcar with more respect.  Its engine is switched off and there is more than enough time for it to cool down before its parts are

Column: 215

cannibalised  at the scrap yard.

 

    We keep one minute of silence - out of respect in memory of the dead.  Perhaps, we can also spare a few minutes of "shut down" time - out of respect for the body of the dead.  These few minutes, as my colleague, Dr Ong Seh Hong, has pointed out, is an important ritual not just for the dead, but also for those alive.  It is the crucial few minutes which allow the loved ones to grieve, bid farewell and do the necessary rituals to send the dead to another world.  Whether it is social, religious or even psychological, any anthropologists and sociologists worth their salt will tell us that it is amongst one of the most important rites of passage in human history, and has great significance to those alive.

 

     The advance of medical science should not be achieved at the expense of our human dignity.  Literature in US suggests that there are medical procedures which can help preserve human organs during what is called the "warm ischemia" time.  The advance of medical science should help us maintain our human dignity.  With the emphasis on the biomedic and life sciences in Singapore, and in our quest to be a regional medical hub, we must be in the lead in such issues in order to be in the league.

 

    All said, HOTA is about saving lives, and I support the Bill.  But I urge the Government to review both the prescribed tests for brain death and the medical procedures for organ transplant from brain dead bodies.

     Among the speakers were two veterans in this House who also spoke on HOTA in 1987:  Mr Chiam See Tong and Dr Tan Cheng Bock.  I checked the Hansard proceedings of that session.  Both of them were consistent in their comments and they remain strong supporters of HOTA all these years, as a way to save lives.  I am cheered by the strong support given by all the Members for this Bill.

    I have listened carefully to all the speeches.  I soaked in all your concerns and reflected on them last night.  And this morning, I went through the media reports to make sure that I did not miss out on any point. 

 

 

    Let me now respond to each of these points.  It will take a while but I hope you will bear with me.  Let me begin with the most talked about issue, which is brain death.  Most Members have expressed concern on this, even though it has been legislated 17 years ago.  For example, Dr Lily Neo asked if the care for the patients, who are potential organ donors, would be compromised.  She asked: would their organs be removed prematurely?  Mr Gan Kim Yong asked if a brain dead patient would suddenly wake up from brain death.  In similar vein, Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked if brain death, in all instances, constitutes death. She and Mr Chiam mentioned the recent case of Ms Tanya Liu, a popular Taiwanese newscaster, who was apparently saved from "brain death" by Prof. Ling Fung of Beijing.  But it was an unfortunate misreporting by the media.  I met Prof. Ling in my office here last month when she was here for a public lecture.  And of course, we talked about Tanya Liu.  She told me how Tanya's sheer determination and strong

Column: 215

family support, and of course combined with good clinical care, contributed to her recovery. But she was never brain-dead.  She was only in coma.

 

 

   Yesterday, Dr Lily Neo talked about an European case, 18 years in coma, suddenly woke up.  I was not aware of that European incident.  But that incident probably inspired a popular Hong Kong TV drama which is currently being screened by Channel U, Hun Qian Hun Hou, "The Awakening Story".  It is about a woman who was unconscious for 16 years and suddenly woke up.  The trouble is that, during the 16 years, the husband had a girlfriend.  So you can imagine: big complications.  My wife is hooked to this nightly drama, every night at 9.00 pm.  As husband and wife should do things together, I too end up following the poor woman's emotional ups and downs.  But, again, this fictitious character was in coma.  She was not brain dead.

 

 

    Given all these sensational news reports and popular TV drama, it is not surprising that lay persons should be confused.  Some would harbour doubts about what really constitutes death.  Mrs Lim Hwee Hua, Mr Iswaran and Mr Gan Kim Yong therefore rightly urged that I give a clear, unambiguous explanation on brain death and, preferably, in simple layman's terms. 

 

     "Brain death" means that all functions of the brain have stopped and stopped permanently.  So it is not quite like what Miss Penny Low tried to explain just now that there are certain brain activities still happening.  The loss of capacity to function is permanent, it is irreversible.  There is irreversible loss of the capacity for consciousness.  There is irreversible loss of the capacity to breathe.  So this invariably leads to the state where all other organs, including the heart, also stop functioning.  So Mr Steve Chia said, "You know, brain death, the heart is still beating."  No, only because the machine

Column: 218

keeps it beating.  And he asked whether "brain death" is completely dead.  Of course.  The fellow is completely dead, unfortunately.  Yes, it is truly, completely, unambiguously and legally dead.

 

 

 

   Hence, unlike coma, brain death cannot be reversed.  A comatose patient, like Ms Tanya Liu was months ago, unconscious but she is alive.  A brain dead is however dead, and not simply unconscious. 

 

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo commented that the definition of "brain death", and I quote her, "is still being debated within the medical profession."  Actually, this is not so.  The issue has already been settled quite some time ago.  So I can assure both Mdm Ho and Mdm Cynthia Phua that, on this point, there is no ambiguity. 

 

 

   Who can determine if a person is brain dead?  To certify brain death, the law requires two doctors to do so, but not just any two doctors.  They must be experienced with specialist qualifications, like our Minister of State, Dr Balaji, and they must be independent:  they must not be involved in the care of the patient, neither must they be involved in the care of the organ recipient.

 

     Mdm Halimah talked about the Greek regime which requires three doctors to certify brain death.  But in almost all countries, like Singapore, we stop at two.  While three is more reassuring than two, two competent and independent doctors are quite sufficient for this purpose.  And in practice, the entire process - if brain death were to lead to a transplant - involves many doctors, as I will explain later.

 

     What constitutes brain death?  There are stringent criteria for the certification of brain death.  And these tests would clearly differentiate between a person who is brain dead and a person who is in coma.  Our doctors adhere strictly to

Column: 219

these internationally-accepted protocol of seven clinical steps to check

 

for the slightest indication of life.  These clinical tests include checking to see whether there is any response to various physical stimuli such as light, touch and pain.

 

 

  Dr Lily Neo asked if we follow the British or the US method of certifying brain death, suggesting that there is a difference between the two.  Just now when I listened to Miss Penny Low, she also read from the Internet about US and the UK and made some comment that the UK seems to be easier, lower threshold than Singapore, again suggesting that there are differences.  I am no expert.  So yesterday I asked Dr Balaji.  Unfortunately, he is now on the way to India or is in India.  He confirmed that, and I quote him here, "Brain death diagnosis in the US, UK and Singapore is medically identical".

 

     In the US, the definition of death is based on state laws. As pointed out by Mdm Cynthia Phua, there are 50 different states; so 50 different ways of defining the same issue.  However, there is a model Bill called the Uniform Determination of Death Act (UDDA) which acts as a template for individual state laws.  This Act was the result of the President's Commission on Brain Death in 1981, and this was more than 20 years ago.

 

     Whole brain death, as defined by this UDDA, is based on three criteria:

 

     (a)  severe coma of known cause;

 

     (b)  absent brainstem function (ie, the six brainstem functions are absent): and

 

     (c)  sustained apnoea (ie, there is no breathing which is the seventh brainstem reflex).

 

Column: 220

     These three criteria are medically identical to the British criteria for brain death, based on the absence of brainstem activity, ie, the absence of the seven reflexes in a comatose patient whose diagnosis is known.

 

     So I am a bit puzzled by Miss Penny Low's recital of what she read in the Internet, suggesting that strange things are happening about brain death definition, and so on.  Unfortunately, I cannot engage her on the technicality, because I am not a doctor and I never pretend to be one.  But I agree with her that so long as there is information out there on the Internet which may be misleading, people in the know have a duty to come up and debunk it.  And we certainly should not in this House propagate such misinformation.

 

     In short, the diagnosis of brain death uses strict specialised medical definitions.  As I said earlier, not all doctors are authorised to certify brain death.  Only qualified specialists are authorised to do so.  In Singapore, they have been doing so since HOTA was first enacted 17 years ago.  The current Bill does not change the way brain death certification will be carried out.

 

     However, there are situations where the seven clinical criteria cannot be fully performed.  For example, one of the tests is on the eyes to see whether there is response.  When the eyes are severely damaged, we cannot perform that test.  The doctors would not be able to test the response if the organs have been injured or if the patient has been sedated and the medications that depress the brain functions are still circulating in the blood.  Then, some of the clinical tests could not be performed.

 

     Each year, we encounter two or three - not many, it is a handful - such cases where organs are damaged, etc.  In such

Column: 221

situations, ancillary tests - like angiography - can be used to measure cerebral blood flow so that brain death can be certified.  These ancillary tests are already used in many developed countries, eg, in the US.  At present, however, our doctors in Singapore are not able to certify these two or three cases who are actually brain dead because our law does not specify such ancillary tests for cerebral blood flow.

 

     My Ministry has, therefore, consulted the National Committee on Neuroscience and is working with the Ministry of Law to amend the Interpretation (Determination and Certification of Death) Regulations to include the tests for cerebral blood flow as ancillary tests to certify brain death in situations like this, where the seven clinical tests cannot all be performed.  Let me stress that ancillary tests are to complement the clinical tests.  They are not substitutes for the clinical criteria.  If six of the seven clinical tests can be performed, then we must make sure we get 6 upon 6.  The criteria for these six tests must be fully met before the doctor proceeds to carry out the ancillary tests in lieu of the seventh criterion.

 

     The bottom line is this: no doctor will think about organ removal when there is still hope for life.  The sole responsibility of doctors is to save the lives of their patients.  The Bill does not change this basic responsibility in any way.

 

     Yesterday, Dr Tan Cheng Bock - unfortunately he is not here - recalled the good old days when the medical practice was a noble profession.  I am not a doctor but my career started in the Ministry of Health during that romantic era.  Dr Tan lamented the slow erosion of the professional values as businessmen and administrators - he probably meant me - marched in and converted a noble profession into an industry.

 

Column: 222

     I have heard of such caricature of the medical service.  I do not fully agree with this description, although I understand the basis for some of this criticism.  This is not the occasion to debate this topic.  But I think Dr Tan knows that I am determined to help like-minded doctors like him, with sound professional values, ensure that medical practice return to the basics, and that is, to cure and relieve suffering and certainly not to bring harm.  Money is a necessary evil but if a doctor is completely motivated by money and nothing else, then I think he or she has joined the wrong profession.

 

     I do not believe that we have in our midst doctors who would be prepared to remove organs prematurely and declare brain death when one is not indicated, so as to benefit from the few dollars of surgical fees that he could get from the donor recipient.  In any case, as I would explain later, we have many safeguards to prevent such a rogue doctor from completing his transaction.  This is Singapore; this is not some third world country that Dr Tan described yesterday.

 

     Mdm Ho talked about phentolamine and heparin and asked if we use these drugs on patients who are brain dead so as to keep their organs alive.  I do not know one from the other.  But the doctors in the Ministry of Health assured me that they do not do so.

 

     So the Bill does not change the concept of brain death.  What is new is that it will now extend HOTA to all deaths beyond accidental deaths.  As I explained earlier, it was an artificial differentiation between accidental and non-accidental deaths, not seen in other countries with HOTA-like legislation.  We should now remove the artificial differentiation so as to save a few more lives.  But the inclusion of non-accidental deaths will not compromise the care of patients.

 

Column: 223

     That is why we have three separate groups of doctors involved in any HOTA transplant.  The first group of doctors looks after the organ recipient; the second group looks after the organ donor; and the third group is responsible for certifying brain death in the donor.  Three totally different, separate, independent groups.  There is, therefore, check and balance to ensure the highest ethical standard is preserved.  In this way, we ensure strict compliance with the requirement that patients' interests will not be compromised in any way.

 

     Let me now respond to the various comments on the choice of organs for HOTA.

 

     Most Members support extending HOTA to include liver, heart and cornea.  As Mrs Lim Hwee Hua puts it, the reasons are compelling.  There were some Members who want us to do more, like Dr Ong Seh Hong.  But a few expressed some reservations, like Dr Lily Neo, about extension to cornea and heart.  Dr Ong Seh Hong and, I think, Mdm Cynthia Phua have mentioned the possible extension to things like the lungs, skin and pancreas.

 

 

    For the moment, the need for skin is less urgent than for kidney, liver, heart or cornea.  The skin bank has 10,000 square centimetres of skin in reserve.  We actually need 40,000 square centimentres to be prepared for a national emergency.  So we are not quite there yet.  But we do have a bit more time to build up this reserve.  For lung transplantation, it is still not fully established in Singapore.  Our first case was only done in the year 2000.  That is why I am reluctant to include skin or lung under HOTA.  Similarly, there are many organ transplant procedures which are not yet well established.  These include pancreas and intestines.  Recently, Members may have read or heard of face transplantation,

Column: 224

where the ethical issues are even more complex. 

 

     Such new developments offer hope to those with organ failure.  However, like all new procedures, there are technical difficulties and considerable risks involved.  I prefer to take a cautious approach.  In any case, we should be sure of public support before we extend HOTA to any new organ.  We have not raised these new organs - skin, lung - during the public consultation, and it is not my style to spring surprises on Singaporeans.  

 

     It is, therefore, better to keep these outside of HOTA for the moment.  But there is nothing to stop us from pursuing these organs under the Medical (Therapy, Education and Research) Act.

 

     In this respect, I share Dr Warren Lee's observation that attitudes towards organ donations are slowly changing.  It is certainly easier now than years ago when we approached the relatives of brain dead patients to consider donating their organs of their loved ones.

 

     My Ministry will keep a close watch on all these new modalities.  I will come back to this House to update the First Schedule of the Act when it is appropriate to do so, so that we keep in line with medical advances.

 

     Yesterday, Dr Neo expressed reservations of some Singaporeans on the extension of HOTA to include cornea.  While they support the extension to liver and heart, they have some problem with cornea as this is not life-saving.  Moreover, foreign corneas are available.  I accept that cornea transplantation is not life-saving.  But the improvement to the quality of life for someone who would otherwise go blind is tremendous.  Mr Zainudin yesterday gave us a fairly good account of the misery of the blind.

 

Column: 225

     Last month, I read a local survey on what Singaporeans with serious myopia will do just to get back 20/20 vision.  Many said that they were prepared to shorten their lifespan by 10% for that.  I was surprised by this survey finding.  But I think this gives us a sense of the value of a cornea transplant, even though it is not life-saving.

 

     Members would know of Dr Lim Suet Wun, CEO of  Tan Tock Seng Hospital.  Dr Lim was one of our anti-SARS heroes.  He led the team in Tan Tock Seng Hospital which played a critical role in our fight against SARS.  So Dr Lim is known to most Singaporeans.  But many will not know that Dr Lim was the beneficiary of cornea transplants many years ago, when I was still a colleague of his in the hospital.  Without the transplants, Dr Lim would effectively be blind.  His subsequent career and contribution to Singaporeans would have been quite different.

 

     I know that there are some Singaporeans who still hesitate to pledge their corneas because of perceived religious concerns.  But the religious leaders have all clarified that there are no religious obstacles to cornea donation.  Part of the misunderstanding is that some people think cornea transplantation means removing the entire eye.  It was so in the past, long long ago, but this is no longer the practice.  Cornea is a thin layer of tissue on the surface of the eye.  So it is not as if the cadavers will be disfigured.

 

     Dr Amy Khor and Mdm Halimah stressed the need for us to respect the dead, certainly not to mutilate or disfigure the bodies.  This is something that we who work in hospitals are extremely sensitive to.

 

     Dr Neo also asked why we are including the heart under HOTA.  As not many heart transplants are done here, why is there a need to include it?  Every

Column: 226

life is worth saving. 

 

    

 

 

There is a Chinese saying, "jiu ren yi ming, sheng zao qi ji fo tu", that is, better to save one life than to build a seven-storey temple pagoda.

 

    Statistically, a few lives saved a year may not be impressive.  But, as pointed out by Mr Gan Kim Yong yesterday, to the individual saved, it means a difference between life and death, and to their loved ones, it means a difference between bliss and misery.  So I think the criteria for inclusion should be whether the operation is now an established treatment modality, and whether there is good public support for such a move.  In fact, when we began our public consultation, the heart was not included.  But the public consultation led us to believe that it is timely to include the heart under HOTA. This also seems to be the conclusion of Mdm Deputy Speaker who mentioned yesterday about a dialogue between the PAP's Women Wing and the professional women.   

 

     Let me now touch on the subject of living donor organ transplant. An entire new section will now be added to the main Act.  As this is something new, it is right for us to spend some time on this and to make sure that we do it right.  However, living donor organ transplant is not new to Singapore.  Many Members have talked about the liver transplant on Ms Andrea De Cruz.  This took place before the Bill. As I have said earlier, we now do more living donor transplants than cadaveric donor transplants for kidneys and livers.  And the trend continues in this direction. The trend of more living donor organ transplantation is definitive.  Mdm Halimah talked about Norway's experience with it.  Dr Baliji told me sometime ago that in Norway, living donor kidney transplant is the norm.  Chronic kidney dialysis is the exception. There, doctors push for live donor organ transplants because they believe that the quality of life for a person on dialysis is poor.  As a result, it is normal in Norway

Column: 227

for a family member to donate a kidney and hospitals actively promote this practice.  Norway is ahead of the curve on this matter. For us, I think the first step is to begin to regulate living donor organ transplantation. 

 

     Here, we have two key objectives.  First, make sure that organ donation for money remains illegal.  The Bill should not become a loophole for organ trading, as warned by Dr Amy Khor.  Second, ensure that we protect our people against donating under duress.  These are key abuses that Dr Neo stressed that we should guard against. To safeguard these, we need a total system approach with multiple checks and balances.  An important player is the Transplant Ethics Committee. Without the committee's authorisation, no transplant can be allowed to proceed.  The committee members have the responsibility of ensuring that each transplant is carried out in an ethical manner.  It is a heavy responsibility as pointed out by many Members.  They have to balance the interest of the donor and the interest of the recipient. 

 

     Mr Iswaran and Dr Tan Cheng Bock argued eloquently on the need for a centralised approach to this, with one national ethics committee, with Ministry of Health's participation, for the entire Singapore.  In this way, we better ensure consistency of approach.  On the other hand, there were Members, like Dr Amy Khor, who saw the value of a decentralised approach empowering the hospital-based Transplant Ethics Committee to take such decisions. 

 

     Actually, our proposed approach is a hybrid, ie, combining the benefits of a centralised and decentralised approach.  At the national level, we have the National Medical Ethics Committee currently chaired by Dr Khoo Chong Yew. 

Column: 228

It was previously chaired by Professor Y Y Ong.  The National Medical Ethics Committee will discuss and forge consensus on policy matters. This group of wise persons will debate and assess what is the society's norm. This will be the platform where guidelines will be formulated for consistent application amongst the hospitals.  Then at the transplant hospital, we will have the hospital's Transplant Ethics Committee which will decide on individual cases of transplants pertaining to their hospital.  At the individual level, a decentralised approach is appropriate.

 

     First, the final responsibility for the care and well-being of both the donor and the recipient rests with the transplant team and the hospital. The hospital-based ethics committee will be better placed to make the detailed assessment and arrive at a correct decision.   Secondly, in some instances, urgent decisions have to be made. In such situations, the hospital's ethics committee will be able to review the case and respond immediately. 

 

     Both the national and hospital ethics committee will comprise members who are wise and who are experienced with sound judgement.  Given the heavy responsibility of these committees, my Ministry will ensure that only respectable persons are appointed. That is why the composition of the ethics committees has to be approved by my Ministry. We all know that ethical decisions cannot be fully codified and converted into formula or computer programmes.  In fact, there will be situations where two wise persons may not agree on the same case.  We should not be surprised by such outcome.  My plan, therefore, is to arrange for occasional discussions amongst the various ethics committees on the cases that they have encountered.  As Mr Iswaran pointed out, in this way, over time, a body of cases will be built up which will help forge the society norms towards such issues.

 

Column: 229

      Mr Ang Mong Seng asked just now how a layman, on such an ethics committee, will be able to play a role on such a medical and technical subject.  But this is not a completely medical subject. When Mr Pierre Png volunteered to donate part of his liver to Ms Andrea De Cruz, the issue went beyond mere medical issues.  In fact, the medical aspects were relatively straightforward.  Was Pierre fit for the operation?  Was he fully briefed on the impact on his health, both during surgery as well as post-surgery?  But beyond these medical issues were many non-medical issues. Why did he volunteer?  What was his relationship to Ms Andrea De Cruz?  Were there any family or societal pressures?  Laymen therefore play a crucial role in the ethics committee, and that is why we make it a requirement. There must be at least one layman.  The strength of the lay person would be in considering social, ethical and non-medical issues.  He or she will try to represent societal views on transplant issues. 

 

     Mdm Cynthia Phua suggested that the term of membership in the ethics committee be time-limited to avoid members becoming too familiar with the hospitals.  I suppose this is akin to company auditors where we do require or encourage rotation of auditors to ensure independence. I agree with the spirit of the suggestion and we will take that into account when considering the proposed composition of the committee.  But I will rather not hard-wire this into the law. The criteria should really be independence and competence.  If a person is proven to be balanced and independent despite being long on the committee, I will prefer to extend this membership, instead of forcing him or her into early retirement.

 

     Besides the structure of the committee, the Bill will also allow my Ministry to set the rules and procedures for the hospital's Transplant Ethics Committee.  This is also a point stressed

Column: 230

by Dr Chong Weng Chiew.  In particular, we will spell out the functions, responsibilities and procedures.  My sense from both the public consultation and the many speeches I have heard in this House is that Singaporeans will prefer that we take a conservative approach to live donor organ transplantation. Where donor and recipient are truly related, the concern is to guard against emotional duress.  Where donor and recipient are not related, the concern is to guard against organ trading. 

 

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock rightly reminded us of the large number of foreign workers here who will be especially vulnerable and potentially a source of exploitation. When a foreign worker, whom a patient never knew, suddenly pops up, claiming to be a distant relative, the antenna of the committee members must immediately pop up too.  Ethics committee decisions are by consensus and this gives veto power to every single member. That is why Dr Amy Khor and Mr Iswaran's suggestion to limit the size of the ethics committee, I think, is not necessary.  In fact, a large committee will make consensus making very difficult.

 

     I worry less about hospitals pressurising the ethics committee to allow transplants than about the pressure from the media.  In any high profile case, public sympathy may often go to the patient, with less regard for the interest of the live donor, especially if he or she is a foreigner.  This is a scenario which I think is likely to happen.  Whatever it is, we absolutely need men and women of strong character and conviction to be in the ethics committee.

 

    Let me now talk about the act of organ trading.  We have a consensus here that it is wrong and we should continue to prohibit it.  Later on, I will talk about some discussions in the West which seem to want to push the boundary on this.  But for the moment, we are all clear about

Column: 231

banning organ trading. The issue is how to ensure that it does not take place in Singapore.  In this regard,  Mr Chiam, Mdm Halimah and Mr Ang Mong Seng felt that our proposed penalty of $10,000 for such a crime does not seem right.  I think Mr Ang Mong Seng suggested $100,000 or $200,000.  Dr Tan Cheng Bock is worried that it might induce people to join in the trade, given the light punishment.  I appreciate the sentiments.

 

     I have not revised the quantum of the penalty because during the public consultation, it was not an issue. Nobody raised this particular point.  But more importantly is that the main instrument to guard against organ trading is the overall framework that I talked about earlier.  Penalty is just one element in this overall framework.  In particular, the role played by doctors and the ethics committee.  I agree with Mdm Halimah that organ trading and organ trafficking involve a long chain of players.  Between the poor donor and the rich recipient - many hands are involved.  But for a transaction to take place in Singapore, many people, including doctors, have to be involved.  Organ removal and organ grafting cannot be learned from the Internet.  A rogue doctor has to have the cooperation of the hospital management, the hospital ethics committee and, in some way, the Ministry of Health, and many other doctors involved in the care of the donor.

 

    For these doctors, the penalty under HOTA, whether it is $10,000, $100,000 or even $1 million, is not a factor.  Their career, reputation, oaths, ethics and responsibility to the Singapore Medical Council are the key factors.  I therefore believe that there are sufficient safeguards in our overall system. That is why we have not revised the penalty quantum. Nevertheless, we will keep the feedback in mind and maintain a watchful eye.

 

Column: 232

     Mdm Ho suggested that we adopt the German practice of enacting an extra-territorial clause which makes it illegal for a German to buy organs anywhere in the world.  The problem there is enforcement and gathering of evidence.  But it is something new in Germany and we will watch over this German experience to see whether we should similarly follow suit. 

 

     Dr Neo asked how the Bill will affect foreign patients seeking transplants in Singapore. Some Members also asked if we will end up a transplantation hub.  Mdm Ho called it - a morbid term - "transplant tourism".  This is certainly not the objective of this Bill or my Ministry.  Our priority is to regulate living donor organ transplantation so as to prevent organ trading.  It is to ensure that there is transparency for all parties involved - the donor, the recipient, the doctors performing the transplant.  It is to ensure that there is objectivity and due process in decision-making.  The Bill will allow us to set up a regulated regime for living donor organ transplants where locals and foreigners coming to Singapore can be assured of high medical standards operating within clear ethical boundaries. We must not become a hub or a player in organ trading, whether consciously or inadvertently. 

 

    Dr Chong Weng Chiew suggested that a database of all living donors be set up so that their post-transplant health can be checked.  I agree.  The Ministry currently maintains such a database. We will work with the transplant physicians and surgeons to monitor the longer term medical and psychological outcomes of the donors.

 

     Let me now discuss the many helpful comments made by the Malay MPs.  First of all, I thank all of them for their courage and support of the Bill.
